Estimating Impacts in Policy Research | NYU Wagner                                    Jump to navigation                                                             Estimating Impacts in Policy Research   PADM-GP.2875, 3 points. Semester: Spring, Fall       Courses         Description |    Syllabi |    Evaluations           This advanced course develops a set of analytic skills that are used by some policy analysts. It focuses on impact analysis. The goals of the course are to (a) extend familiarity with methodologic issues, including various study designs, measurement problems, and analytic approaches; (b) provide hands-on experience in management, analysis, and presentation of data; and (c) develop skills in reading, critiquing, and reporting on policy-relevant impact analyses written by others. The emphasis of the course is on learning by doing, through data analysis, data presentation, and study critiquing activities. Students work on developing the ability to convey findings in text and table format.    Prerequisites: PADM-GP.2171 and PADM-GP.2902.                     Semester     Instructor     Syllabus Link         Spring 2015 Jan Blustein Syllabus  Fall 2014 Jan Blustein Syllabus  Spring 2014 Jan Blustein Syllabus  Spring 2013 Jan Blustein Syllabus  Fall 2012 Jan Blustein Syllabus  Fall 2011 Jan Blustein Syllabus  Fall 2010 Jan Blustein Syllabus  Spring 2010 Elena Elkin Syllabus  Fall 2009  Syllabus  Spring 2009  Syllabus  Fall 2008 Jan Blustein Syllabus                         Semester     Instructor     Evaluation Link         Spring 2014 Jan Blustein Evaluation  Fall 2013 Jan Blustein Evaluation  Spring 2013 Jan Blustein Evaluation  Spring 2012 Mijanovich, Tod Evaluation  Fall 2011 Blustein, Jan Evaluation  Spring 2011 Mijanovich, Tod Evaluation  Fall 2010 Blustein, Jan Evaluation  Spring 2010 Elkin, Elena Evaluation  Fall 2009 Mijanovich, Tod Evaluation  Fall 2008 Blustein, Jan Evaluation  Spring 2008 Elkin, Elena Evaluation  Spring 2009 Morreale, Joseph Evaluation                             Course Section Fall2015001 Spring2015001                         Instructors:        Blustein, Janice                              Weekly Schedule:        Tue - 6:45 pm to 8:25 pm                     Session Dates:        09/02/2015 to 12/15/2015                                  Location:         Bldg:GCASL Room:261                                      Instructors:        Blustein, Janice                              Weekly Schedule:        Tue - 6:45 pm to 8:25 pm                     Session Dates:        01/26/2015 to 05/11/2015                                  Location:         Bldg:GCASL Room:365

                                                                                                      About Silver                                                             Academics                                                             Admissions                                                                                Research                                                             Our Faculty                                                                                                                               Research Strengths                                                             Centers and Institutes                                                             Information for Practice                                                                                                                    Research                                                                                                                                                                                            Faculty Profile       Wen-Jui Han                                                                                                  Current Project       Just Do You                                                                                                  Faculty Profile       Vincent Guilamo-Ramos                                                                                                                                   Faculty Profile       Deborah Padgett                                                     The Silver School’s faculty is well known for its quality and diversity of research and for examining society’s most pressing problems.                                                                                                                                                                                                     Leaders in the field of social work, Silver School faculty members are creating knowledge for the future of the profession. Faculty research spans a range of topics, but the School is particularly well known for its innovative work around poverty; children, youth, and families; and mental health and clinical science. Faculty members address issues in New York and the United States, but they also conduct work farther from home—challenges facing the indigenous people of Guatemala, conducting community needs assessments in the Philippines, and the influence of tourism on HIV-risk behavior in the Dominican Republic. The School has a strong emerging program in global social work. In addition, the School’s research centers and institutes foster and disseminate research targeted at issues important to social work. The School is home to the only centralized web resource covering professional news and new scholarship from around the world, Information for Practice .                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Centers and Institutes                                                                                                   McSilver Institute for Poverty Policy and Research      Center for Latino Adolescent and Family Health      Center on Violence and Recovery      NYU-ECNU Institute for Social Development at NYU Shanghai                                                                                                                                                                                                                Online Resource for Social Workers                                                                                                   Information for Practice (IP) is a unique international resource for social care/social welfare/social work professionals that focuses on aggregating news and new scholarship for professional practice. IP is a constantly updated, free service. Semester: Spring, Fall       Courses         Description |    Syllabi |    Evaluations           This advanced course develops a set of analytic skills that are used by some policy analysts. It focuses on impact analysis. The goals of the course are to (a) extend familiarity with methodologic issues, including various study designs, measurement problems, and analytic approaches; (b) provide hands-on experience in management, analysis, and presentation of data; and (c) develop skills in reading, critiquing, and reporting on policy-relevant impact analyses written by others. The emphasis of the course is on learning by doing, through data analysis, data presentation, and study critiquing activities. Students work on developing the ability to convey findings in text and table format.    Prerequisites: PADM-GP.2171 and PADM-GP.2902.                                             Admissions                                                                                Research                                                             Our Faculty                                                                                                                               Research Strengths                                                             Centers and Institutes                                                             Information for Practice                                                                                                                    Research                                                                                                                                                                                            Faculty Profile       Wen-Jui Han                                                                                                  Current Project       Just Do You                                                                                                  Faculty Profile       Vincent Guilamo-Ramos                                                                                                                                   Faculty Profile       Deborah Padgett                                                     The Silver School’s faculty is well known for its quality and diversity of research and for examining society’s most pressing problems.                                                                                                                                                                                                     Leaders in the field of social work, Silver School faculty members are creating knowledge for the future of the profession. Faculty research spans a range of topics, but the School is particularly well known for its innovative work around poverty; children, youth, and families; and mental health and clinical science. Faculty members address issues in New York and the United States, but they also conduct work farther from home—challenges facing the indigenous people of Guatemala, conducting community needs assessments in the Philippines, and the influence of tourism on HIV-risk behavior in the Dominican Republic. The School has a strong emerging program in global social work. In addition, the School’s research centers and institutes foster and disseminate research targeted at issues important to social work. The School is home to the only centralized web resource covering professional news and new scholarship from around the world, Information for Practice .                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Centers and Institutes                                                                                                   McSilver Institute for Poverty Policy and Research      Center for Latino Adolescent and Family Health      Center on Violence and Recovery      NYU-ECNU Institute for Social Development at NYU Shanghai                                                                                                                                                                                                                Online Resource for Social Workers                                                                                                   Information for Practice (IP) is a unique international resource for social care/social welfare/social work professionals that focuses on aggregating news and new scholarship for professional practice. IP is a constantly updated, free service.
